item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: http:.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded: Hi! My name is Desislava Milusheva and I am a Junior Java developer. At the moment I study a bachelor's of Computer Science at Technical University in Sofia, Bulgaria. My coding journey began eight years ago when I was still in school. And programming is still my big passion. I have still a lot to learn but in my opinion, the best way to prove your knowledge is to pass it on to someone else. So that is why I created this blog and I hope I can help you еven with something. Enjoy it!

item.title: The Information In Our World
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
As you all know these days, information is everywhere. Tons of information flows are moving around us. So today we will track - how we have learned to process and use all of this information. But first, what does the word INFORMATION mean? The term information comes from the Latin word "informatio" which means information. In general, it can be said that information is knowledge, information from the world around us, which is used to interact with it.
Ever since ancient times, people have sought opportunities to retrieve, transmit, present and use information. People communicated with each other through speech and thus exchanged knowledge and ideas. But at some point, this information had to be stored so that it could be disseminated even more easily. The ancient people painted on the walls of the caves they inhabited. Thus, they passed on basic knowledge, such as hunting, to future generations. A little later, the writing appeared, as well as various accounting systems (for processing numerical information). People begin to record their knowledge of books. Sciences such as mathematics, physics, philosophy, etc. are being developed. Printing machines appear. And at the end of the 20th century, the computer was invented. People's various attempts to automate the processing of information over the centuries can be summarized in three main stages.

From ancient drawings to the printed books

The first attempts to record information were ancient drawings on stone, wood, and earthenware. Hieroglyphs appear in ancient Egypt About 3000 BC. And in the coming centuries, many other scriptures of different nations appeared. People begin to write their knowledge first on papyrus, and later on paper and books. In the beginning, everything is handwritten until the printing machine is invented and the whole process is automated. People are given much greater access to information and new knowledge, which gives a great impetus to human development.

17th century

We can say that the person has been trying to automate the processing of information since ancient times. An example of this is the abacus.
In 1602 the logarithmic scale was invented. And this was just the beginning of a new era. Between 1642 and 1673 Blaise Pascal creates a machine for addition and subtraction, and then Gottfried Leibniz refines it by adding multiplication.

19th century

In 1820 Charles Thomas de Colmar invented the first commercially successful mechanical calculator, the Arithmometer.
Charles Babbage was an English polymath and mechanical engineer who originated the concept of a digital programmable computer. In 1833 he proposed the design of a machine (Analytical Engine) representing a true computer model with a central processor and a patch.
He was considered by some to be a "father of the computer".
In 1890 the American businessman and inventor Herman Hollerith developed the electromechanical tabulating machine for punched cards to assist in summarizing information and, later, in accounting. His invention of the punched card tabulating machine, patented in 1884, marks the beginning of the era of semiautomatic data processing systems. In 1896 Hollerith founded The Tabulating Machine Company. In 1911 four corporations, including Hollerith's firm, were amalgamated to form the Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company (CTR). Under the presidency of Thomas J. Watson, CTR was renamed International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. By 1933 The Tabulating Machine Company name had disappeared as subsidiary companies were subsumed by IBM.

20th century

Entering the new century, technology development was gaining more and more speed.
One of the major contributors to the development of computer science was Alan Mathison Turing. He was highly influential in the development of theoretical computer science, providing a formalization of the concepts of algorithm and computation with the Turing machine, which can be considered a model of a general-purpose computer. Turing is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. During the Second World War, Turing worked for the Government Code and Cypher School at Bletchley Park, Britain's codebreaking center that produced Ultra intelligence. For a time he led Hut 8, the section that was responsible for German naval cryptanalysis. Here, he devised a number of techniques for speeding the breaking of German ciphers, including improvements to the pre-war Polish bombe method, an electromechanical machine that could find settings for the Enigma machine.
There is no way I missed mentioning Andrey Markov Jr. who was a Soviet mathematician and one of the key founders of the Russian school of constructive mathematics and logic. He made outstanding contributions to various areas of mathematics, including differential equations, topology, mathematical logic and the foundations of mathematics. His name is in particular associated with Markov's principle, Markov's rule, and Markov algorithm.

Many machines and devices have been developed in the coming years to make data analysis faster and easier.
The German engineer Konrad Zuse invented the world's first programmable computer Z3 in May 1941. It was the world's first working programmable, fully automatic digital computer. The Z3 was built with 2,600 relays, implementing a 22-bit word length that operated at a clock frequency of about 4–5 Hz. The program code was stored on punched film. Initial values were entered manually.  
In the years 1943–1945 British codebreakers created Colossus. It was a set of computers developed to help in the cryptanalysis of the Lorenz cipher. Colossus is thus regarded as the world's first programmable, electronic, digital computer.
Howard Hathaway Aiken was an American physicist and a pioneer in computing. Inspired by Charles Babbage's difference engine, he envisioned an electro-mechanical computing device that could do much of the tedious work for him. This computer was originally called the ASCC (Automatic Sequence Controlled Calculator) and later renamed Harvard Mark I. With engineering, construction, and funding from IBM, the machine was completed and installed at Harvard in February 1944. Three years later, Aiken completed his work on the Harvard Mark II computer. He continued his work on the Mark III and the Harvard Mark IV.

John Atanasoff was best known for being credited with inventing the first electronic digital computer in the 1930s. Challenges to his claim were resolved in 1973 when the Honeywell v. Sperry Rand lawsuit ruled that Atanasoff was the inventor of the computer. His special-purpose machine has come to be called the Atanasoff–Berry Computer.
Between 1944 and 1946 John Mauchly along with John Eckert, designed ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer), the first general-purpose electronic digital computer, by using the idea of Atanasoff. It was able to solve "a large class of numerical problems" through reprogramming. The two professors design four machines together and the successor to ENIAC is EDVAC (Electronic Discrete Variable Automatic Computer). In 1949 they created BINAC (Binary Automatic Computer). It was an early electronic computer designed for Northrop Aircraft Company. And in 1951 was created UNIVAC I (UNIVersal Automatic Computer I). It was an electronic digital computer design for business applications.
On April 29, 1952, IBM started selling the first commercial scientific computer IBM 701 (Electronic Data Processing Machine) and in 1965 was created the model System/360. From August 1980 IBM started a significant production of personal computers.

In 1976 the Apple Computer Company released a desktop computer  Apple-1. It was designed and hand-built by Steve Wozniak. The idea of selling the computer came from Wozniak's friend Steve Jobs. The Apple-1 was Apple's first product.
On November 20, 1985, Microsoft introduced an operating environment named Windows as a graphical operating system shell for MS-DOS in response to the growing interest in graphical user interfaces (GUIs). Microsoft Windows came to dominate the world's personal computer market with over 90% market share, overtaking Mac OS, which had been introduced in 1984.

21st century

And here we are, in the age in which we live now. The 21st century is the age of new, rapidly evolving technologies. So now I will stop here and let the time show how far our technological development will go.

Ever since ancient times, we have been interested in the world around us and we were looking for knowledge. From cave drawings to modern computers, our development is constantly speeding up so let's see where it takes us.

item.title: Your First Java Program
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
The Java language is easier to understand (and write) than languages such as C and C++. The biggest reason for this is that Java doesn’t use pointers. Some people are surprised that pointers aren’t necessary for the creation of complex data structures and algorithms. In fact, eliminating pointers makes such code not only easier to write and to understand but more secure and less prone to errors as well. Java is a modern object-oriented language, which means we can use an object-oriented approach for programming examples. This is important, because object-oriented programming (OOP) offers compelling advantages over the old-fashioned procedural approach, and is quickly supplanting it for serious program development.

What is OOP and which are its basic concepts?

When we say that Java is an object-oriented programming language we mean that Java is a language in which programs are considered as a collection of objects. Each object is nothing but an instance of a class. There are four principle concepts upon which object-oriented design and programming rest. They are:

Abstraction - refers to the act of representing essential features without including background details or explanations. It shows only the necessary details for an object, not its inner details. Example: A car in itself is a well-defined object, which is composed of several other smaller objects like a gearing system, steering mechanism, engine, which again have their own subsystems. But for humans car is one single object, which can be managed by the help of its subsystems, even if their inner details are unknown.

Polymorphism - can be briefly described as "one interface, many implementations". But if you do not know what is an interface, let's say that polymorphism is a characteristic of being able to assign different meaning or usage to something in different contexts - specifically, to allow an entity such as a variable, a function, or an object to have more than one form.
Example: If we have class Animals. For this example, animals can be cats or dogs. Animals make sounds but the sound of the cat is "meow" and the sound of the dog is "bark". The two sounds are different but they are still sound and they are made from the animals - cat and dog.

Inheritance - it is a concept where one class shares the structure, properties of object and behavior defined in another class. A class that is inherited is called a superclass and the class that does the inheriting is called a subclass.

Encapsulation - is a technique used for hiding the properties and behavior of an object and allowing outside access only as appropriate. It prevents other objects from directly altering or accessing the properties or methods of the encapsulated objects. Levels of encapsulation are public, protected and private (they are called access modifiers). We will discuss them later.

What is Class?

A class is a template from which individual objects are created in the memory. A class can contain fields and methods to describe the behavior of an object. At its core, a class definition is a block of code, delimited by braces “{” and “}”, within which is included declarations of instance variables and methods that are the members of the class. In this section, we will undertake a deeper examination of class definitions in Java.

What is Object?

An object is termed as an instance of a class, and it has its own state, behavior, and identity.

Now, let's make a simple overview of the Java programming language and begin our Java primer with a program that prints “Hello Universe!” on the screen.

In Java, executable statements are placed in functions, known as methods, that belong to class definitions. The Universe class, in our first example, is extremely simple - it has only one method, which is executed when we run the Java program. Any set of statements between the braces “{” and “}” define a program block.
The name of a class, method, or variable in Java is called an identifier, which can be any string of characters as long as it begins with a letter and consists of letters, numbers, and underscore characters.

We already said that the key-word public is an access modifier and it tells that access is possible from everywhere. For example, our class can be accessed from other classes and e.g. Between the braces of the class, we have one method. Its name is main(). A Java program begins execution with its main() method and it is the gateway to the startup of a Java process. It keeps our code long enough available to do the work we’ve coded.

Let’s now review the words in the main() method’s signature, one at a time. The keyword static means that the method can be invoked without instantiating an object. Java doesn’t need to create an object to call the main() method—which is good since you haven’t learned about creating objects yet! The keyword void represents the return type. A method that returns no data returns control to the caller silently. Finally, we arrive at the main() method’s parameter list, represented as an array of objects. In practice, you can write String[] args. The variable name args hints that this list contains values that were read in (arguments) when the program is started. In the body of the method between the second brackets, we are using a command that prints text on the console (in our case the text is "Hello Universe!").

So, this was a really simple program with some explanations for beginners. Well done! Just keep studying. 😉

item.title: What Are Data Structures and Algorithms?
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
As you start learning Java or some other object-oriented programming language, you are going to get familiar with Data Structures and Algorithms. And maybe you will have some questions:

  • What are Data Structures and Algorithms?
  • What good will it do me to know about them?
  • Why can’t I just use arrays and for loops to handle my data?
  • When does it make sense to apply what I learn here?

This blog post attempts to answer these questions. For those of you who haven’t yet been exposed to an object-oriented language or Java, you can read my previous post. Now let's get started and learn something more about Data Structures and Algorithms.

What Are Data Structures and Algorithms?

A data structure is an arrangement of data in a computer’s memory (or sometimes on a disk). Data structures include arrays, linked lists, stacks, binary trees, and hash tables, among others.

Algorithms manipulate the data in these structures in various ways, such as searching for a particular data item, sorting the data, insert a new data item or delete a specified item.

Maybe you are wondering what sorts of problems can you solve with a knowledge of these topics? Let's say that there are three useful categories:

  • How to Handle Real-World Data Storage?
    By real-world data, I mean data that describes physical entities external to the computer. As an example, one phone book describes real phone contacts with people. It will have the following information for each entry - first name, last name, phone number, address. You might find yourself with questions like these:

    - How would you store the data in your computer’s memory?
    - Would your method work for a hundred records? A thousand? A million?
    - Would your method permit quick insertion of a new record and deletion of old ones?
    - Would it allow for fast searching for a specified record?
    - How would you sort the records in alphabetic order?

    As you learn about Data Structures and Algorithms, you will begin to find answers to these questions and problems.

  • Data Structures for Programmers
    Not all data storage structures are used to store real-world data. Typically, real-world data is accessed more or less directly by a program’s user. Some data storage structures, however, are not meant to be accessed by the user, but by the program itself. A programmer uses such structures as tools to facilitate some other operation. For example, stacks, queues, and priority queues are often used in this way.

  • World Modeling
    Some data structures directly model real-world situations. The most important data structure of this type is the graph. You can use graphs to represent airline routes between cities or connections in an electric circuit or tasks in a project. Another example is the queue, which can model customers waiting in line at a bank.

item.title: Classes In C#
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
In this post, I am going to introduce you to the basics of classes. I will show you a real-world example of classes and why we need them. Then you will see what is an object and how it is different from a class. Finally, you will learn more about static members.

What Is a Class?

A class is a building block of a software application. Applications consist of multiple classes, each responsible for a particular behavior. All these classes together will provide the behavior expected from the application.

Let's take a look at a real-world example. We all are familiar with the concept of blogs and posts. Let's say we would like to implement a web application as a blog engine with typical layered architecture. Our application will consist of at least three layers. Presentation, business logic which also referred to as domain layer, and data access which is also referred to as the persistence layer.

In each of these layers, we can have classes each responsible for something particular. For example, in the presentation layer, we can have a class like a PostView, which is purely responsible for displaying imposed to the user. In the business logic or domain layer, we can have the concept of the Post itself. And finally, in the data access or persistence layer, we can have a class like a PostRepository, which knows how to save as opposed to the database or loading from a database.

A real-world application often consists of hundreds or even thousands of classes collaborating with a shudder. So for you, as a C# programmer, it is absolutely crucial to understand classes and how to use them effectively, in order to build a maintainable, clean, robust and reliable application.


The class essentially has two parts - data which is represented by fields and behavior which is represented by methods or functions. Here is how we illustrate a class in UML or unified modeling language.



So in UML, a class has three parts. The first part is the name of the class, e.g. Person. Then there are fields or attributes of that class, which represent data about that class, e.g. Name, Age, Height, Weight. And finally, we have the methods or functions which provide some behavior, e.g. Walk(), Talk(), Eat(), Sleep().

A term that is often used with classes, is an object. But what is it?
An object is essentially an instance of a class, which resides in the memory. So back to our Personal example. If Person is a class, we can have objects like John Mary and Scott. These are instances of that person.

The person class or the person type defines the blueprint from which we can create objects at runtime. These objects into memory, talk to each other and as a result, we get the behavior expected from the application. Now let's see how we can declare a class in C#.

Here's a basic syntax for declaring a class. public and class are reserved keywords in C#. That is why I have indicated them with blue. Word public is what we call an access modifier and that is something you're going to learn later in this section.

Each class should have a name or an identifier like Person. In terms of the naming convention in C#, we use Pascal Case for naming the classes. In Pascal Case, the first letter of every word should be upper case. We also have Camel Case, in which the first letter of the first word should be lowercase and the first letter of every word after that should be uppercase. In C# we use Camel Case when naming parameters of methods as you will see later in the section.

//So back to the declaration of our class, the class can have fields and methods which we refer to as members of that class. It put members inside this curly braces here we can declare a field for this class and call it name similar to the class we start with an access modifier. In this case public and the data type for that field and an identifier in the real world applications we shouldn't declare fields with public. This is purely for taking you on a step by step journey without confusing you with a lot of details along the way. As we progress in this section you'll find the best way to declare fields. OK now let's see how we can declare a method in this class or similar. So we start with an access modifier. And here is the signature of the method. So a method that can have a return type. In this case void means it doesn't return any value and it has an identifier. And here in brackets we can't put any prompter's that that method may need inside the method.

We have the code and here we can access any of the members of that class.

So in this example I'm simply using console dot write line to display the name of that person on the

console.

OK now that we have a class let's see how we can create an object or an instance from it to do that

b is the new operator.

So we start with the type of the class.

In this case person we give it an identifier and then we use the new operator along with the name of

the class to initialize an instance of that class.

Note that here we are using common notation for naming the person object.

A shorter way to write this go is to use var.

Var is a C-sharp keyword.

And the reason we use that used to save us from typing the full name of the class because sometimes

the name of the class might be quite a few characters.

Plus as you see it's a little bit of duplication.

To repeat the name of the class in two places.

So we use the VAR keyword and the compiler automatically knows that this person object is of type person

.

Now that we have an object we can access members of that object like accessing the name field and giving

a value.

Or we can call one of its methods before we start coding.

Let's talk about class members in C-sharp we have two types of class members.

You have instance members and static members and instance member is accessible from an object you have

already seen that before.

So we create the person object and then call the Introduce method on the object.

But we also have stunning members and static member is accessible from the class not an object.

An example of that is console that right like a console is a class and right line is a static method

.

So we don't have to create an instance of console using the new operator in order to call right line

.

Now you may wonder why do we use a static members.

Basically we use them to represent concepts that are a singleton.

That means we should have only one instance of that concept into memory.

Think of the concept of the current day time we should have only one place in the memory where we know

the current day time.

It doesn't make sense to have different objects.

It's telling us that current day time is a different value.

item.title: What Are Web Services? Why Are They Useful?
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
If you are wondering what web service is, keep reading. I will introduce to you the two different types of web services and the java standards that deal with these web services.

What is a Web Service?

Imagine that you have two applications - a Java application running on a Linux environment and a .NET or Python application, running on a Windows environment. Now, the question is how these two applications can communicate with each other. Is there any easy way, if we have in mind just the fact that they are running on a different environment.

Maybe if you think, there is a really simple solution. What if there is some kind of communication bridge between both applications. Web services are XML-centered data exchange systems that use the internet for A2A (application-to-application) communication and interfacing. These processes involve messages, programs, documents, and objects.

In simple words, web service is every software, application, or even cloud technology that communicates on the network through the HTTP / HTTPS protocol. It exchanges messages or data as XML (Extensible Markup Language) or in various other formats like JSON.

Now, when you know what kind of animal is the web service, let's say again why they are so useful. If we have two applications, which are written in different languages, they can communicate with each other by data or message exchange, via a web service between client and server. A client calls on the web service by sending an XML request, then the service returns an XML response.

Before we continue, I want to explain to you two or three definitions:
XML
JSON
protocol (HTTP/HTTPS)

Service-Oriented Architecture (SOA)

When we say web service some developers may associate it with SOA (Service-Oriented Architecture). SOA is a collection of architectural principles to design and implement our software applications in such a way that they are composed of several software services that have simple well-defined interfaces and can use each other in a loosely coupled manner.

In other words, SOA is a way of developing software, which provides services to other components via network communication ports.

Let's define what a service is according to the SOA standard, using a Hospital Management application example. Service according to SOA is an implementation of business logic that operates independently of the state of another service.

Here is a Hospital Management application wherein we have an Appointment Management service which allows a patient to schedule an appointment with a doctor. This Appointment management service is consuming the Patient Service to get the patient information and then the Doctor Service to get the doctor's schedule and make an appointment.

Similarly, the Doctor Service consumes a Clinical Service which gives the Doctor Service the data of a particular patient. That is the clinical data of a patient. Similarly, we have a Bed Management application that can be used to allocate a bed if a patient is being checked in. All these components are not clubbed into one single application but they are separated out into services and they are deployed on their own. They communicate with each other in a loosely coupled passion using a standard interface. Meaning, as long as this interface here between the Doctor Service and the Clinical Service remains the same, we can replace this particular Clinical Service with a new Clinical Service we write. Or if the hospital purchases a Clinical Service from a different company, they can use it as long as this contract between these two remains the same.

This contract, in case of SOAP web services, is the WSDL file and in the case of REST web services, it is the WADL file. The data format that is used to exchange messages between these services in SOA is XML because XML has both data as well as metadata which tells what to do with that data.

Let's look at some of the advantages of SOA. And as we go through them you see that web services pretty much have the very same advantages and that is the reason why web services are the key to implement SOA. The first and foremost advantage is the platform independency. That is, SOA applications should be able to run on multiple platforms and they can communicate with each other. So if an application running on .NET or Linux environment or Windows environment can easily communicate or should easily communicate with a service running on Linux which is written in Java. SOA allows developers to have focus on roles so that they can specialize in an area. Going back to our previous example a set of developers can specialize in a Doctor Management application, a set of developers can focus on a Bed Management service, Clinical Management service so on, and so forth. Loosely coupled which I have already explained.

As long as the interface remains the same, an application or a service that is a consumer of another service can easily be switched to another service that provides the same functionality because we use standard and loosely coupled interfaces. Since we have split the services or the application into multiple services, if we need a particular functionality we can easily reuse it across our application.

To summarize, SOA stands for Service Oriented Architecture and it is a set of principles. Web services are a way to implement those principles in applications that we create.

Types of Web Services - SOAP and REST

They are two different types of web services. The first is the big web services or SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) web services which used XML-based messages on the HTTP post method. So the web service provider and consumer, in this case, communicate using SOAP which is an XML, and they use HTTP post to do the message exchange.

Secondly, the even more powerful RESTful (REpresentational State Transfer) web service which uses all the methods available in the HTTP protocol as a standard and then they support multiple data formats, that is the big feature of RESTFul web services along with XML they support JSON, etc.

Each language and platform has standards for implementing these two types of web services. They provide us with tools to implement the SOAP as well as RESTful web services.

  • JAX-WS stands for JAVA API for XML based web services and it is a standard for implementing SOAP-based web services.
  • JAX-RS stands for JAVA API for RESTful web services and it is a standard for implementing RESTful web services.

SOAP as Web Service

SOAP is defined as Simple Object Access Protocol. This web service protocol exchanges structured data using XML and generally HTTP and SMTP for transmission. SOAP also uses WSDL (Web Services Description Language) documents to distribute a web service description model. This describes how the SOAP requests (client-side) and responses (server-side) must appear. Additionally, SOAP web Services have standards for security and addressing.

            Pros: Usually easier to consume, more standards (WSDL, etc.), distributed computing

            Cons: Difficult set-up, more convoluted coding, harder to develop

item.title: Network vs. Internet: What Are The Differences?
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
What is a Network?

The network is two, three or more connected computers, servers, or other devices which share data resource like an internet connection, printers, etc.

Which are the Main Types of Networks?

There are four main types of networks, depending on their size :

  • LAN - Local Area Network

    LAN is a group of computers, which are connected together with each other in a small network such as building, office.

  • PAN - Personal Area Network

    PAN is a network within a range of about 10 meters, for example, in your home, which is used for connecting personal devices like computers, laptops, mobile phones, media players, or even play stations.

  • MAN - Metropolitan Area Network

    A metropolitan area network is a network that covers a larger geographic area by interconnecting a different LAN to form a larger network.
  • Government agencies use MAN to connect to the citizens and private industries.
  • In MAN, various LANs are connected to each other through a telephone exchange line.
  • The most widely used protocols in MAN are RS-232, Frame Relay, ATM, ISDN, OC-3, ADSL, etc.
  • It has a higher range than Local Area Network(LAN).

  • WAN - Wide Area Network

    A Wide Area Network is a network that extends over a large geographical area such as states or countries.
  • A Wide Area Network is quite bigger network than the LAN.
  • A Wide Area Network is not limited to a single location, but it spans over a large geographical area through a telephone line, fibre optic cable or satellite links.
  • The internet is one of the biggest WAN in the world.
  • A Wide Area Network is widely used in the field of Business, government, and education.

item.title: Какво е Microservice ?
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
Microservice -ите стават все по-популярни поради успеха, който компании като Netflix, Amazon и Apple са постигнали с тяхна помощ. Мicroservice -ите са добро решения за съвременни софтуерни изисквания, като предоставят възможност за лесно и бързо надграждане на една система и независимост на отделните й компоненти. В този пост ще научите за основните принципи на microservice -ите, изграждащите ги блокове и как са внедрени в различни технологии.

Какво представляват microservice -ите?

Microservice -ите са малки, слабо свързани приложения или service -и, които могат да работят заедно в една система, но ако един от тях се срине или има проблем, това не се отразява на остнаналите. Когато microservice не работи, само един процес в системата трябва да стане недостъпен, докато останалата част от системата остава незасегната.

Представете си едно мобилно приложение на банка, в което може да се регистрира нов потребител, а вече съществуваш потребител може да прави определени транзакции или да тегли кредит. Всички тези функции работят заедно в приложението, но какво ще стане, ако модулът отговарящ за регистриране на нови потребители има проблем или се срине. Това по никакъв начин не трябва да пречи на остнаналите потребители да правят своите транзакции, т.е. сриването на един от модулите или microservice -ите, не трябва да засяга цялата система. Системата трябва да може да продължи да работи.

item.title: Защо да използваме MockServer?
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
От английски, mocking означава да имитираме/репликираме нещо или някого. Така че, е доста лесно да декодираме, че MockServer, вероятно ще има общо с репликиране на сървър. Тоест ще създадем изкуствен сървър, който ще е копие на истинския и ще имитира негововто поведение. Ще deploy-нем този "сървър-имитатор" и ще изчакаме да видим respose-a, който ще бъде върнат. Важното тук е, че ако има проблем или бъде хвърлена грешка, засегнато ще бъде само копието, а ние можем спокоино да продължим работата си и да отстраним грешките, без дори да имаме жив сървър. Има много други причини да работим с mockserver-и и да ги за внедряваме в ...

------------------------- допълнение-------------------------------------------------------

В света на компютърните технологии, server-ът е компютърна програма или устройство, което осигурява функционалността на други програми или устройства, наречени клиенти (clients) .
Функционалностите или услугите, които server-ът може да предостави са множество, като започнем от споделяне на данни или ресурси между множество клиенти до извършване на изчисления за клиент.
Един сървър може да обслужва множество клиенти, а един клиент може да използва множество сървъри.
Моделът request/response се използва най-вече за имплементиране на клиент/сървър системи, т.е клиентът изпраща request до сървъра, който извършва някакво действие и връща response обратно на клиента, което може да бъде някакъв очакван резултат или дори съобщение за грешка.
Както ще видим по-долу, това е същият модел, на който разчита HTTP server-ът.

Дефиниция за web или HTTP server
Web server-ът или HTTP server-ът е сървърен софтуер (или хардуер, поддържащ работата на сървърния софтуер), който реализира request/response модела, използвайки World Wide Web и HTTP (протокол.)
HTTP server-ът обработва входящите мрежови request-и от клиентите по протокола HTTP и предоставя (serve) съдържание през интернет.

Какво представлява HTTP и как работи?
Протоколът за HTTP или Hypertext Transfer Protocol е application layer protocol, който се използва за виртуално предаване на файлове и други данни в световната мрежа, независимо дали те са HTML файлове, файлове с изображения, резултати от request-и или нещо друго. С по-прости думи, HTTP е универсален, говорим език с проста граматика, който позволява бърз „превод“ и по-лесна комуникацията между клиента и сървъра, като описва как информацията трябва да бъде поискана (request-ната) и как да се формират respons-ите. Обикновено HTTP се основава на TCP/IP протоколите, така че се осъществява чрез TCP/IP socket-и.

Какво прави HTTP server-ът?
Основната функция на HTTP server-а е да съхранява, обработва и доставя уеб страници до клиенти, използващи HTTP протоколи.
Клиент или по-добре казано потребителски агент (user agent), който е софтуер, действащ от името на потребител (обикновено представен от уеб браузър), инициира комуникация чрез отправяне на request за конкретен ресурс, използвайки HTTP към сървъра, (приложение, работещо на компютър, host-ващ уебсайт).
Server-ът, който предоставя ресурси като HTML файлове и друго съдържание или изпълнява други функции от името на клиента, връща response в отговор на клиента.
Response-ът, обслужван от server-а, съдържа информация за състоянието на завършване на request-a и може също да съдържа requested content in its message body, or an error message if it is unable to serve the content.

Here is an analogy pulled form a previous answer I gave to a similar question:
The cook in the kitchen that prepares the meal to be served. Programmers write the recipe (php code) that the cook (php) executes in the kitchen (server) using ingredients from the pantry (database) to create the dish (content) that is served by the waiter (http) to the table (browser) for the diner (user) to consume. For an interactive site replace dish with menu and note that the waiter (http) goes both ways and delivers an order from the diner back to the kitchen (server) where the cook (php)can process it.

------------------------- допълнение-------------------------------------------------------

За всяка система, която се интегрирате чрез HTTP или HTTPS, MockServer-ът, може да се използва като:
- "сървър-имитатор", конфигуриран да връща конкретни respons-и за различни request-и
- прокси запис и по избор промяна на заявки и отговори
едновременно прокси за някои искания и макет за други искания едновременно
Когато MockServer получи заявка, тя съответства на заявката спрямо активни очаквания, които са били конфигурирани, ако не се намерят съвпадения, той прокси на заявката, ако е подходящо, в противен случай се връща 404.
За всяка получена заявка се случват следните стъпки:
намерете съвпадение на очакванията и извършете действие
ако няма съответстваща заявка за прокси очакване
ако не прокси заявка връщане 404
Очакването определя действието, което се предприема, например отговор може да бъде върнат.
MockServer поддържа следните действия:

Една от най-големите (и определено не най-лесните) части на развитието е интеграцията с външните услуги. Нашите приложения комуникират с външния свят почти при всяка молба. Но по време на процеса на разработване и QA искаме да сведем до минимум въздействието на външната логика върху системата - буквално казано - да накараме външния API да се държи така, както ние го искаме. Ключът за това е макетният сървър.
Какво е макет сървър
Мокет сървърът е самостоятелно приложение, което се върти до системата за разработка и позволява на други системи да изпращат заявките към него и отговаря с предварително дефинирания набор от данни. Най-общо казано, това е заместител на истинския API, който искаме да избегнем повикване. Основните случаи на употреба са:

MockServer-ът не е реален сървър. Това е изкуствено създаден сървър, който симулира работата на истинския, като идеята му е да можем да тестваме API-та и да проверим response-ите или error-ите, които се връщат.
Този сървър е настроен по такъв начин, че за конкретен request, който желаем да видим, получаваме конкретен response.
MockServer-ът се държи като истински сървър, но използва фалшиви API-та, разбира се, с цел тестване и разработка.
Има редица причини, поради които се нуждаем от mockserver-и. Наред със случая, даден по-горе, той се изисква и в днешния тестващ свят. Такова изискване е в методологията Agile, която е наскоро и е по-добра от методологията на водопада. При този метод тестването и разработката вървят рамо до рамо. За това тестерът трябва да има същото изискване като разработчика, за да работи едновременно. За което имате нужда от макет сървър. В допълнение към това в следващия раздел са изброени няколко причини.

item.title: Java Reading List: My TOP Books About Programming
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
Reading books is one of the best ways to improve your craftsmanship and to become a better software developer. This is a continuously updated list with my favourite programming books, sorted by topic. I link to the ebook version where possible but most books should be available made from dead trees as well.

Architecture & System Design

How to build reliable software that works well.

  • Release It! by Michael T. Nygard
  • The Architecture of Open Source Applications by Amy Brown
  • The Architecture of Open Source Applications, Volume II by Amy Brown
  • The Performance of Open Source Applications by Tavish Armstrong

Craftsmanship

Books about best practices, code quality and professionalism. Every single one of these books is fantastic and I got so much out of them. If you don’t know which area to focus on first then start here.

  • Clean Code by Robert C. Martin
  • Team Geek by Brian W. Fitzpatrick
  • The Clean Coder by Robert C. Martin
  • The Passionate Programmer by Chad Fowler
  • The Zen Programmer by Christian Grobmeier
  • HBR’s 10 Must Reads on Managing Yourself
  • Better: A surgeon’s notes on performance by Atul Gawande
  • Code Complete by Steve McConnell

Programming Languages

Books about specific programming languages that I enjoyed. There’s often free resources available online but sometimes it’s nice to just buy a book that takes you through many aspects of a language. Some of these books are great reads even if you’re not interested in the language specifically, as they teach you important universal concepts.

Haskell

  • Learn You a Haskell for Great Good! by Miran Lipovača
  • Parallel and Concurrent Programming in Haskell by Simon Marlow

JavaScript

  • Effective JavaScript by David Herman
  • JavaScript: The Good Parts by Douglas Crockford

Python

  • Writing Idiomatic Python by Jeff Knupp
  • Effective Python by Bret Slatkin
  • Python Cookbook, 3rd Ed. by David Beazley and Brian Jones
  • Two Scoops of Django by Daniel and Audrey Roy Greenfeld
  • Fluent Python by Luciano Ramalho
  • Automate the Boring Stuff with Python by Al Sweigart

Scala

  • Programming in Scala by Martin Odersky

Interviews & Hiring

These books work both ways. If you’re trying to be hired as an engineer or hiring others then you can learn a lot from them.

  • Elements of Programming Interviews (Python Ed.) by Aziz, Lee and Prakash
  • Cracking the Coding Interview by Gayle Laakmann McDowell
  • Programming Interviews Exposed by John Morgan

Leadership & Managing developers

These are useful even if you’re not in a leadership position. They’ll help you understand your manager better and will make you a more effective communicator.

  • Managing Humans by Michael Lopp
  • Leading Snowflakes by Oren Ellenbogen
  • How to Win Friends & Influence People by Dale Carnegie
  • It’s Not All About Me by Robin Dreeke

CompSci fundamentals, algorithms, and math

This stuff is important. Languages and frameworks come and go but the foundations remain largely static. Re-visit these every once in a while.

  • The Algorithm Design Manual by Steven S. Skiena
  • Algorithms by Dasgupta, Papadimitriou, and Vazirani
  • Introduction to Algorithms by Thomas H. Cormen
  • Concrete Mathematics by Ronald L. Graham

Postmortems

The best software engineering war stories around. I get inspired by reading about successful or failed software projects that others have worked on. These books let you learn from the experiences and careers of some of the best people in the field.

  • Coders at Work by Peter Seibel
  • FoxTales by Kerry Nietz
  • Masters of Doom by David Kushner
  • Postmortems from Game Developer by Austin Grossman
  • Showstopper by G. Pascal Zachary
  • The Future Was Here: The Commodore Amiga by Jimmy Maher
  • The Making of Karateka by Jordan Mechner
  • The Making of Prince of Persia by Jordan Mechner

Writing

Being able to communicate succinctly in writing is often more important than raw technical ability. Especially if you want to convince others. These books have helped me to structure my thinking and improved my English. Especially if English is your second language like it is for me this is an area you should focus on.

  • On Writing Well by William Zinsser
  • Oxford Guide to Plain English by Martin Cutts
  • Writing for Computer Science by Justin Zobel

item.title: Real Time Analytics On Data Streams: Kafka + Druid + Superset (part 1)
item.dc:creator: desi109
item.content:encoded:
One popular trend in the data world recently is the rise of stream analytics. Organizations are increasingly driven to build solutions that can provide immediate access to key business intelligence insights through real-time data exploration. Architecting a data stack to transmit, store, and analyze streams at scale can be difficult, engineering feat without the right tools. Luckily, existing open source solutions can be combined to form a flexible and scalable streaming analytics stack. In this blog post, we will use Apache {Kafka, Superset, Druid} to set up a system that enables immediate exploration and visualization of event data.

So now I want to show you an example of how to create interactive real time dashboards on data streams. But first, let me explain to you a little more about Kafka, Druid, and Superset.

Apache™ Kafka is a publish-subscribe message bus that is designed for the delivery of streams. The architecture of Kafka is modeled as a distributed commit log, and Kafka provides resource isolation between things that produce data and things that consume data. Kafka is often used as a central repository of streams, where events are stored in Kafka for an intermediate period of time before they are routed elsewhere in a data cluster for further processing and analysis.

In this setup, Kafka is used to collect and buffer the events, that are then ingested by Druid. We need Kafka to persist the data and act as a buffer when there are bursts of events, that happen.

Apache™ Druid is a real-time analytics database designed for fast slice-and-dice analytics on large data sets. It provides real-time data ingestion from Kafka, flexible data exploration, and fast data aggregation. For example, when the data is being generated by the users, or sensor, or whatever, it flows in the application landscape. Where it is processed and it flows into your database where it is directly available for querying.

Apache™ Superset is a web application that provides an intuitive interface to explore and visualize datasets and create interactive dashboards.

So let's start!

Prerequisites
Software
- Java 8 (8u92+)
- Linux, Mac OS X, or other Unix-like OS (Windows is not supported)
Note: If you use Windows, you can install Virtual Machine on your device as I am using Ubuntu.

Hardware
- 4 CPU
- 16 GB or 8 GB RAM environment
- Hard disk - 120 GB

After installing the VM, open your favorite terminal and set up a few things.
Check your java version. 

java -version

If your java version is not Java 8 or it is missing, install it.

sudo apt install openjdk-8-jdk-headless

Superset does not ship bundled with connectivity to databases, except for SQLite, which is part of the Python standard library. You’ll need to install the required packages for the database you want to use as your metadata database as well as the packages needed to connect to the databases you want to access through Superset. In our example, this database is Apache Druid. 

sudo apt install python-pip
pip install pydruid

Starting Druid
First, download and extract the Druid distribution.

tar -xzf apache-druid-0.17.0-bin.tar.gz
cd apache-druid-0.17.0

From the apache-druid-0.17.0 package root, run the following command:

./bin/start-micro-quickstart

After running this command DO NOT close the terminal. Allow the process to charge.

Starting Kafka
Download Kafka then open a new terminal. Follow commands to extract the file and open the directory: 

tar -xzf kafka_2.12-2.1.0.tgz
cd kafka_2.12-2.1.0

Start a Kafka broker by running the following command in a new terminal: 

./bin/kafka-server-start.sh config/server.properties

After running this command DO NOT close the terminal. Allow the process to charge.
Then in a new terminal run this command to create a Kafka topic called wikipedia, to which we'll send data: 

./bin/kafka-topics.sh --create --zookeeper localhost:2181 --replication-factor 1 --partitions 1 --topic wikipedia

After the process is done, you can keep running your commands in this terminal.

Load data into Kafka
Let's launch a producer for our topic and send some data!
Run the following command:

cd apache-druid-0.17.0
cd quickstart/tutorial
gunzip -c wikiticker-2015-09-12-sampled.json.gz > wikiticker-2015-09-12-sampled.json

Run the following command, where {PATH_TO_DRUID} is replaced by the path to the Druid directory (e.g. /home/user/apache-druid-0.17.0 ) :

cd kafka_2.12-2.1.0
export KAFKA_OPTS="-Dfile.encoding=UTF-8"
./bin/kafka-console-producer.sh --broker-list localhost:9092 --topic wikipedia < {PATH_TO_DRUID}/quickstart/tutorial/wikiticker-2015-09-12-sampled.json

The previous command posted sample events to the wikipedia Kafka topic. Now we will use Druid's Kafka indexing service to ingest messages from our newly created topic.

Starting Superset
Superset stores database connection information in its metadata database. For that purpose, we use the cryptography Python library to encrypt connection passwords. Unfortunately, this library has OS level dependencies. Here’s how to install them:

For Debian and Ubuntu, the following command will ensure that the required dependencies are installed:

sudo apt-get install build-essential libssl-dev libffi-dev python-dev python-pip libsasl2-dev libldap2-dev
sudo apt-get install build-essential libssl-dev libffi-dev python3.6-dev python-pip libsasl2-dev libldap2-dev

Python virtualenv
It is recommended to install Superset inside a virtualenv. Install virtualenv useing the next commands: 

pip install virtualenv
python3 -m venv venv
. venv/bin/activate
pip install --upgrade setuptools pip

So now it is time to install Superset. Follow next commands:

pip install apache-superset
superset db upgrade
$ export FLASK_APP=superset
flask fab create-admin

Whit the las command we want to create an admin user (you will be prompted to set a username, first and last name and e-mail before setting a password). Next command:

superset load_examples
superset init
superset run -p 8088 --with-threads --reload --debugger

After that allow the process to charge.
